title: Red Eye, Watering, and Photophobia: A Clinical Guide
summary: Red and watering eyes are among the commonest ocular presentations in primary care. While often benign and treatable by GPs, the presence of photophobia or atypical features like visual symptoms often signals severe ocular pathology requiring detailed examination.

sections.title: Clinical Overview & 1° Care
sections.content: Common clinical presentations: red eye, watering, and photophobia. Red (see Table 18.11) or watering eyes (see Table 18.12) are among the commonest ocular presentations in 1° care. Often these are relatively benign conditions, many of which may be successfully treated by GPs. However, in the presence of atypical features (particularly visual symptoms), more serious diagnoses should be considered. The presence of photophobia (also see Table 18.13) is usually an indication of more severe ocular pathology.

sections.title: Red Eye: Table 18.11 (Normal VA)
rows: Gritty, often itchy, discharge, diffuse superficial injection ± lid papillae/ follicles
FB sensation, FB visible or in fornix/ subtarsal, local injection, corneal abrasions (if subtarsal FB)
Mild local pain, sectoral superficial injection (constricted by phenylephrine)
Severe pain; deep, often diffuse injection; complications may lead to dVA
Gritty pain, localized injection, conjunctival/ corneal nodule
Abnormal conjunctival blood vessels, usually chronic ± systemic vascular abnormalities

sections.title: Red Eye: Table 18.11 (Reduced VA)
rows: Photophobia, watering, sectoral/ circumlimbal injection, epithelial defect
Photophobia, watering, circumlimbal injection, corneal infiltrate ± epithelial defect ± AC activity
Photophobia, watering, corneal oedema, iIOP anterior segment/ angle abnormalities
Photophobia, watering, KPs, AC activity ± PS
Pain, floaters, watering, diffuse deep injection, inflammation (vitreous > AC), hypopyon, chorioretinitis

sections.title: Watering Eye: Table 18.12 (i tears)
rows: Chronic gritty, irritable eyes, poor tear film quality, meibomianitis
Gritty, often itchy, discharge may be sticky, diffuse superficial injection ± lid papillae/ follicles
FB sensation, FB visible or in fornix/ subtarsal, local injection, corneal abrasions (if subtarsal FB)
Photophobia, sectoral/ circumlimbal injection, epithelial defect
Photophobia, sectoral/ circumlimbal injection, corneal infiltrate ± epithelial defect ± AC activity
Photophobia, injection, corneal oedema, iIOP ± anterior segment/ angle abnormalities
Photophobia, circumlimbal injection, KPs, AC activity ± PS

sections.title: Watering Eye: Table 18.12 (d drainage)
content: Nasolacrimal duct obstruction: Chronic watering (may have sticky discharge) without other ocular signs ± lacrimal sac swelling

sections.title: Photophobia: Table 18.13 (Anterior)
rows: Watering, sectoral/ circumlimbal injection, epithelial defect
Watering, circumlimbal injection, corneal infiltrate, epithelial defect ± AC activity
Watering, circumlimbal injection, KPs, AC activity ± PS
Watering, injection, corneal oedema, iIOP, anterior segment/ angle abnormalities
Complete/ partial absence of tissue (e.g. aniridia, coloboma), mydriasis, or non- pigmentation (albinism)

sections.title: Photophobia: Table 18.13 (Posterior & CNS)
rows: Pain, floaters, watering, diffuse deep injection, inflammation (vitreous > AC), chorioretinitis, hypopyon
Cone deficiencies (achromatopsia, blue cone monochromatism) or later- onset dystrophies
Headache, aura, nausea, vomiting, positive visual phenomena
Fever, headache, neck stiffness, altered mental state, neurological dysfunction, normal ocular examination

sections.title: Reference Data
sections.content: 873 RED EYE, WATERING, AND PHOTOPHOBIA. Abbreviations used: VA (Visual Acuity), FB (Foreign Body), dVA (decreased Visual Acuity), iIOP (increased Intraocular Pressure), AC (Anterior Chamber), KPs (Keratic Precipitates), PS (Posterior Synechiae).
